name: Turkey Tail Mushroom
summary: Turkey Tail (Trametes versicolor) is a medicinal mushroom rich in polysaccharopeptides like PSK and PSP, studied for immune support, gut health, and potential adjunctive cancer therapy.
description: Turkey Tail (Trametes versicolor) is a widely distributed medicinal mushroom traditionally used in Asian medicine. It contains bioactive compounds such as polysaccharopeptide (PSP) and polysaccharide-K (PSK), which have immunomodulatory, antioxidant, and prebiotic properties. Clinical studies, particularly in Japan and China, have investigated PSK as an adjunctive cancer therapy with evidence of improved survival in some cancers. Turkey Tail is also studied for supporting gut microbiome health, immune function, and resilience against infections, though more high-quality human trials are needed.

metadata.natural_source: Fruiting body and mycelium of Trametes versicolor
metadata.prescription_status: Dietary Supplement (PSK is prescription in Japan)
metadata.fda_status: Dietary supplement in the U.S.; PSK approved in Japan as adjunctive cancer therapy

primary_indications: Adjunctive therapy in cancer (e.g., gastric, colorectal, breast, lung)
monitoring_required: Immune markers if used adjunctively with cancer therapy

items: Used as adjunct therapy in some cancers, particularly in Asia (PSK/PSP extracts)
Promotes gut health through prebiotic polysaccharides

sections.text: Turkey Tail contains bioactive polysaccharopeptides such as PSK and PSP, which modulate immune function by stimulating natural killer (NK) cells, dendritic cells, and T-cells. They also exhibit antioxidant properties and act as prebiotics, influencing the gut microbiome. PSK, in particular, has been shown to extend survival in certain cancers when used with chemotherapy.

adult.typical: 1–3 g per day of dried extract (capsules, powders, teas)
adult.note: In Japan, PSK is used at 3 g/day as a prescription adjunctive cancer therapy.

sections.pediatric: Not well established; should only be used under clinical supervision.

sections.text: Immune and microbiome effects may appear within weeks; cancer adjunctive benefits studied over months to years.

other: Not a substitute for standard cancer treatments.
Safety in pregnancy and breastfeeding not established.

items.action: Used as adjunct in clinical protocols (esp. in Japan)

sections.pregnancy: Insufficient safety data; avoid unless medically supervised
sections.pediatrics: Not well studied; avoid outside clinical trials
sections.geriatrics: Generally safe but monitor for digestive tolerance

sections.text: No formal taper required; can be discontinued without withdrawal.

items: PSK (Krestin) is a standardized extract approved as a cancer adjuvant in Japan.
PSP has been studied in China with similar immunomodulatory results.
May be synergistic with conventional oncology treatments but should never replace them.

items.label: Eliza WL, et al. Clinical trials of Coriolus versicolor PSP in cancer. Int J Med Mushrooms. 2012
